Assault Pack Design Review:
FILBE vs Kahakka

01 Feb 2026

Propper International FILBE vs Savotta Kahakka 25L
America vs Europe

Article Description: This is an in-depth gear review of two "military" backpacks (American and Finnish). From here on, it'll get more technical and critical. You've been warned.

This is a comparative design and quality review of the FILBE Assault Pack (AP), used by the United States Marine Core (USMC), and the Savotta Kahakka 25L Backpack, a commercial version of the M20 pack used by Finnish Defense Forces (FDF).

Propper FILBE

Savotta Kahakka

Savotta M20


How do two military assault packs,
one from the USA's defense powerhouse,
the other born from Finland's sisu,
measure up?


While characterizing this as an “Europe vs America” is a bit unfair, It may be unfair because:
1)The Kahakka is made for commercial, not military sale
2) Different manufactures (Propper vs Eagle Industries) may have differing qualities, independent of home country
3) Propper and Savotta don’t make all the backpacks (or equipment) for all of American and Finish armed forces. it is still worthwhile to compare the design considerations and build quality between products fulfilling similar roles across the Atlantic. Some of the noted findings do seem to highlight the cultural and stereotypical differences between the countries (USA vs Finland) in question.

Testing duration: Both of these backpacks have been tested for at least 1 year.

Relevant Experience: I have never been in combat. I have played a lot of milsim sports. I have solid engineering and user design experience.

The principal considerations are:

  1. Everyday Carry Use (EDC)
  2. Combat Usage (CU)
  3. Manufacturing and Quality

I will refer to each pack as the FILBE Typically, FILBE refers to the main rucksack (80L) in the FILBE system, not the assault pack. Here I will just refer to it as the FILBE.and Kahakka from here on.

Summary of differences (TLDR)

The FILBE is bigger and heavier, The FILBE has a larger volume, even if the tech specs say otherwise. capturing the American design ethos. The Kahakka is smaller and leaner, demonstrating the European one.

For everyday and short-term combat usage, the design of the FILBE is superior. The FILBE's simple compartment system ensures quick and effective organization. Its J-Zip provides great ease-of-access. In contrast, the Kahakka's top flap closure is inconvenient, especially for items at the bottom of the pack. The hunter's green PU inner lining makes visibility in the compartment difficult. For long term combat usage and poor weather, the Kahakka's design may be better because of improved defense against the elements, excepting a lack of drainage grommets.

The FILBE is more comfortable with heavier loads due to wider, better padded straps. It is cooler on the back because of the dual-channel padding. This advantage is negated while wearing a plate carrier. For travel, the Kahakka is 0.5 kg lighter. Notably, the actual body height is only 40cm (not the advertised 48cm), meaning if not overstuffed, it meets RyanAir's small bag dimensions (40x30x20cm). The FILBE (~51 cm) will require bending if tested.

While aesthetics are mostly opinion, it can affect every day carry and how others react to you. The FILBE clearly carries a military air, while the Kahakka less so. I have been prevented from entering certain museums and areas of interest while wearing the FILBE, although this was during the European Terror waves (2015-2017). I think it is less likely I would have been stopped with the Kahakka, but still possible.

The quality of the Kahakka is simply superior - both in terms of material and build. The manufacturing quality of the FILBE has, in my limited experience, significantly regressed since its release.

For EDC, where I must access items readily, the FILBE is the clear choice. For hiking, the decision comes down to season, and carry needs. In hot weather or heavy carry loads, the FILBE is my choice. For cold weather and general travel, the Kahakka is better.

Introduction and History

If you’re here, you likely already have an interest in at least one of these bags. Therefore, I’ll be concise with the history.

The Family of Improved Load Bearing Equipment (FILBE) Assault Pack (AP) was first fielded by the USMC sometime in 2011-2012. As of 02/2026 (right now), it is still the AP in service for the USMC. It was produced by both Eagle Industries and Propper International. Only in late 2024 did it become available for consumer purchase from Propper. However, it was available as military surplus as early as 2013-2014.

The Kahakka was released to the consumer market in 2024, making it some 12 years younger. It is based on the the FDF’s M20 pack, with learnings from the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine.

Why I care so much about this (and why it matters to you!)

I had the same backpack for 9 years (RIP 2015-2024). It was used at least as many days as I’ve had it, probably more.

Sometimes it hardly carried anything but papers, other times it was stuffed to the brim, camping gear strapped to the side. It was with me as I rode the métro and walked the streets of Paris to university. It was with me when I reached the foot of the glaciers on Mont Blanc. It’s seen the beaches on both sides of the Atlantic, and beaches on both sides of the Mediterranean, not forgetting Corsica in the middle. It’s been over the Alps, Apennines, Appalachians, Blue Stacks and Derryveaghs, and even graced the Lake District. It’s survived a dozen different farms, carried books into at least 4 different universities, and most importantly, had a pocket just for holding a fresh baguette.


That pack was the FILBE


FILBE Assault Pack with a backdrop of Mont Blanc, Europe's tallest mountain.

When you’ve carried something like that for so long, it becomes a part of you, and an icon of yourself. Folks recognize you just by its silhouette. When I tested other bags, my friends didn’t like it. “You should get a new one of the same bag. It’s like it’s not you anymore,” they said.


And, I didn't really want a new bag


Unfortunately, after 9 years of wear-and-tear, my original FILBE needed to be replaced. It wasn’t so much the standard usage which got it, but an early accident. I left it against a radiator in a caravan (that wasn’t supposed to work), waking during the middle of the night to the odor of burning plastic. The melted holes became weak points no patching seemed to resolve. Eventually, one huge tear formed at the top of the bag, perpetually letting in rain.

The rip


It was time for a new bag - but which?


Whatever replacement pack came, it would be would have big shoes to fill. My FILBE had been part of my life for just shy of a decade. I knew it inside and out.

Buying a new one seemed the obvious choice. But, a new FILBE direct from Propper would cost $180. Used ones could be had for much less. “Like-new” ones however were not acceptably cheaper to risk getting one with holesIt was not possible at the time to physically visit a military surplus store that might have one for physical inspection., likely leading to the same demise as the previous.

So, I cared a lot about getting a new pack, and the right one. And it matters because whatever pack would come next would have to meet high standards.


Enter the Kahakka


At about this time, I was interested in The Road to Vostok, an indie game (still in the making as of 02/2026) whose fictional Finnish setting somewhat mirrors that of the Chornobyl and Pripyat Exclusion zones in Ukraine (and similarly is taken advantage of by the STALKER video game series). It also at that time that Road to Vostok gained its first commercial collaborator: Savotta.

Savotta is a well-known Finnish supplier of outdoor gear, for both military, police, and recreational use in “extreme-environments.”

"We are Savotta and we make military gear"


If that doesn't convince you to buy one of their products (or want to be Finnish), well then, you're clearly not me.


Although it was more expensive than purchasing a new FILBE, I decided to take the plunge. I purchased my Kahakka for €185 or $205 (purchased at 10% discount) back in October of 2024 . I would also end up purchasing a new FILBE for the price of $180 a few months later.

Technical Specifications

Comparison table of tech specs. Skip this if too much detail:

Below is a detailed specifications comparison of the FILBE vs Kahakka. Color coded pieces depict my opinion based on experience. It does not highlight where one pack is better or worse than the other, though this is usually the case, but it highlights implementations better or worse than “standard”.

Guide:
Blue: Very Good
Black: Standard, Acceptable
Yellow: Questionable or Uncertain
Red: Bad

First Impressions

(Note: 02/2026 - will update with comparison photos of the 2025 FILBE and 2024 Kahakka)

The first time I saw the Kahakka, side by side with the FILBE, I thought, "…and this is the difference between America and Europe."

Front View

Right Side View – Hole on top of the FILBE is partly visible

Top-Front View – The hole in the top of the FILBE is partly visible

Back View – Age related fraying on the FILBE is visible

Traveling between the USA and Europe tends to result in what I call “aspect ratio shock.” It’s akin to changing the aspect ratio on your TV, like 16:10 to 4:3, in an instant - just with real life. I haven’t heard anyone else get this sensation, but if you do, it’d be nice to know I’m not alone.

If you go from Europe to the USA, maybe for the first time or in a long while, it suddenly feels like everything has gotten flattened and horizontally expanded. The roads are so wide that a “single lane” in American suburbia feels equivalent to a rural double lane in the European countryside. Even the landscapes themselves seem to stretch out further.

Going to Europe from the USA is the opposite. Everything becomes taller and skinnier. Older European continental homes have such high ceilings that jumping does not permit touching them (for any normal person). In Europe, everything seems thinner - from the fencing to the sign posts - because it is. Just look at the difference between American and European printing paper formats. Americans love their 8.5″x10″ sheets, and Europeans their 8.3″x11.7″.

More generally, American products are heavier, bulkier, and luxurious (in the sense of comfort). European products are lighter, maintain economy of material, and spartan. Cars are a perfect example, even from the same manufacturer. American cars are larger. Even when comparing the same car model, just between continents, American suspensions are far softer. While European products are trimmed, this also means they’re fitted.

You can observe this in how the average person dresses in Europe versus the USA. Europeans are better dressed. They tend to wear tight, hemmed clothes, pants that aren’t jeans, and aren’t necessarily blue (or black or khaki), sweaters over their button up long-sleeve shirts, and nice shoes. Each pair of socks they own are are unique. Not dozens of pairs of the same exact sock. And well….Americans, they wear that one-size-fits-all from Costco, baggy jeans, and if they’re a older father, those “classic” 608 V5s (because well, they are comfortable).

As an experiment, I gave Nano Banana Pro the following image generation prompt:

“Imagine me stereotypical images of American man average clothing and average European”



And that is the FILBE vs Kahakka in a nutshell.
The FILBE is baggy, spacious, heavy, and more comfortable. It is a brute of a bag.
The Kahakka is thin, tight, and light. It is a precise pack.


Overview

Each aspect of the packs will be reviewed and compared in this section. Again the main considerations are for EDC (Everday Cary), Combat Use (CU), and build quality.

Two terms worth highlight are Single Handed Usage (SHU) and Fine Motor Control (FMC). These are important concepts in military applications (to me) because they determine how readily a product can be used when injured (single handed usage case) and/or when under extreme stress where fine motor control becomes reduced.

Main Compartment

Main Compartment Access

The Main Compartment is the heart of every pack. Access to the main compartment on the Kahakka is through a fold top lid secured by 2 side release (SR) buckles. The female ends of these buckles are note worthy because they have flared entrances, similar to a flared magwell. This is the first time I’ve seen this on an SR buckle, though I’m sure they exist elsewhere. It’s a strong design choice - it does make buckling easier, especially in stressful situations where fine motor control goes out this window.

Front of pack with 2 SR buckles and their flared inserts.

In comparison, the FILBE uses a J-zip, so named because the zipper is stretches longer down one side than the other.

FILBE Main Compartment

In terms of opening the main compartment, it might be argued that the Kahakka is easier. It only requires one hand to unlatch the buckles, and then lift the lid. The FILBE has two zippers, but they do not slide freely enough without some additional force on the bag to keep it in place. Therefore, one handed usage is easier on the Kahakka, but accessing specific items is more challenging.

Unbuckle the Kahakka’s main SR clips and the fold top lid extends open. This system is common in many recreational hiking packs. Fold top lids are great because they eliminate the weaknesses of zippers while leveraging the pack’s shell to keep out the elements. But for an assault pack, I’m not convinced they are the right choice.

While opening can be done single handed, this system doesn’t provide easy access to materials in the compartments, except those placed at the top. When the fold top lid opens, the folding portion becomes an extended neck. In effect, the pack becomes a longer tube. Bottom access is challenging. My arm length is typical to that of a 6’ or 183cm tall man. As an EDC example, putting the Kahakka on cashier’s counter and trying to put in groceries in an organized manner to maximize space usage and not crush anything, is actually really hard. I ultimately stopped using the Kahakka as an EDC mainly for this reason.

One solution to this is often found in larger hiking packs with fold top lids. At the bottom, there is a zippered “sleeping bag section.” However, when everything must be packed from bottom-to-top, things will inevitably get pulled out of the pack onto the ground for access. I can’t imagine having to fidget with any of this , fold top lid or even a sleeping bag zipper, in combat when some sort of ammunition, medical supply, etc. has made its way to the bottom or some unknown position. For this, the J-Zip on the FILBE is far more convenient.

However, one redemption of the implementation in the Kahakka’s fold top lid is a a plastic insert in the lower lip (towards bottom of picture below). This little flexible piece does the job of keeping the mouth of the lid open and squared. I know it’s a rectangle, but “rectangled” doesn’t read as smoothly as a verb There is however a seam on this lower lip which is sharp and seems to catch a lot. I was concerned how this seam would hold up in time, but after more than a year it is no worse for wear.

Plastic Insert on bottom lip keeps opening squared. Seam on bottom is "rough" where there is a 45 degree in the material.

Main Compartment Organization

The Kahakka has limited organization in the main compartment - a single pouch for a hydration bladder. The top of the pouch is kept under tension by an internal elastic band. There are 3 togs providing anchors to a bladder, though only one is visible in my photo.

I am not a fan of elastic tensioning because these materials eventually “dry out,” losing their elasticity and ability to do their job.

There is one particular grievances I have asked the Kahakka - its internal PU coating. This is a great idea to increase weather resistance. But, this particular coating is a hunter’s green (i.e. very dark green). I know not if this was intentional, such as a carry over from procurement specifications for the M20. Explcitly, to reduce any potential of an offending light signature leaking from inside the main compartment at night. But ultimately, this dark coating makes locating anything, even on a sunny day, frustrating.

My constructive advice would have be to use a lighter material to reflect light further down the cavity, and if needed, use a darker coating only at the very top, and/or on the outer pouches, for concealment.

Kahakka Organization
Visible: elastic hydration bladder
"Hello darkness my old friend…"

In comparison, the FILBE has simple but more developed organization. A zippered mesh pocket sit at. It is very easy to access, even just opening the main J-Zip slightly, and it’s easy to see what’s inside due to the mesh covering. I have found this particular useful for EDC and travel for items like keys and IDs.

The FILBE features a radio comparment, which can be used to hold hydration a hydration bladder. Unlike the Kahakka, it does not have locking anchors for the bladder, presumably because these would get in the way of the radio. In my own experience with the FILBE and a water bladder, the lack of anchors makes little difference. The radio pouch features a strap with buckle, something which is preferred over the elastic of the Kahakka’s elastic band.

Both the Kahakka and FILBE have exit slots for water bladder tubes (or radio antennae for the later). I heavily prefer the flap coverings that Savotta has used. They are located on each side of the flip top lid, just above the hemming in my photos, towards the rear of the packs. The exit slots on the FILBE are covered by Velcro and part of the top carrying handle. Despite rarely using these, they show great wear at this stage. Their top placement makes them less than ideal for inclement weather, but this may be a necessity for the intended radios antennas.

The FILBE also features 2 internal side pockets or “canteen” pouches. One is the “Baguette holder”, a long pocket tube seen in the folder below. The second is the “Grenade holder” on the other side. It’s not clear to me what either is explicitly for. The Baguette holder, besides holding baguettes, is useful for cables, chargers, and dongles as an EDC. Speaking of baguettes, another benefit of the J zipper, is being able to partially close the pack, while having extended object secured in the main compartment (like a baguette). As for the Grenade holder, I’ve found little utility for it except for rolled socks.

Finally, the main compartment also features a zipper for access to the plastic rear panel, just above the radio pouch. This is actually an additional “compartment.” In the past I’ve used this pouch to store documents and hide back-up cash while traveling as the zipper goes unnoticed. It is strange that a zipper was incorporated here instead of a material as it would’ve likely lowered production cost and weight.

FILBE Organizaton (J-Zipper open)
Visible: radio pouch, mesh pocket, baguette holder, and back panel access.

One final note of the main compartment - the Kahakka emplys no drainage grommets while the FILBE utilizes 3 (and 2 for the front pouch). Drainage grommets permit water to escape should it manage to get inside. The Fins and the Marines are focued on rather different geographic sectors. The lack of grommets may be due to the Finnish Defense Forces pack requirements, which again, I am wholly ignorant of, and they may have requested no external openings for drainage. The Fins may prefer the the “Hardshell” philosophy - “Never give water a chance to get in, and you won’t get wet.”

On the otherhand, with the USMC being focused on maritime operations, and taking the “Softshell” philosophy - “You will get wet no matter what, so keep the door open” - it’s no surprise that even their hot weather boot has drainage grommets.

Bottom of the FILBE - The FILBE has 5 drainage grommets, 3 in the main compartment (1 visible here, 2 outlines of the others can be seen under the PALS webbing) and 2 in the front pouch.

Bottom of the Kahakka (no grommets)



















BELOW IS A DRAFT

A Comparative Review with the USMC FILBE Assault Pack (Europe vs America)

This is a review of the Savotta Kahakka 25L (October, 2024). Unlike most reviews of the pack, this one is critical. Here I compare the new Savotta Kahakka (2024) with my previous backpack, another military assault pack. Feel free to skip the rambling Introduction by going to, “First Impression – and Numbers”

Introduction

I’ve had the same backpack for 9 years (RIP 2015-2024). It’s been used at least as many days as I’ve had it.

Sometimes it hardly carried anything but papers, other times it was stuffed to the brim, camping gear strapped to the sides. It was with me as I rode the métro and walked the streets of Paris to university, it was with me when I reached the foot of the glaciers on Mont Blanc. It’s seen the beaches on both sides of the Atlantic, in the USA and Ireland, and beaches on both sides of the Mediterranean, France and Italy, not to forget Corsica in the middle. It’s been over the Apennines, Appalachians, Blue Stacks and Derryveaghs, and even graced the Lake District. It’s survived a dozen different farms, carried books into at least 4 different universities, and most importantly, had a pocket just for holding a fresh baguette.

This backpack was the FILBE Assault Pack.

FILBE Assault Pack with a backdrop of Mont Blanc

And here are more scenic photos with the pack…

Another view from the Alps, with the two glaciers coming off the Mont Blanc mountain block. My other boot fell down shortly before taking this photo

Propriano, Corsica

Somewhere in the middle of Corsica, I don’t even know where. Shortly after the heater incident which burnt holes in my at the time, new FILBE.

So, any backpack replacing my FILBE Assault Pack (AP) was going to have big straps to fill. And why replace the FILBE AP if it was so cherished?

Simple, 9 years of wear and tear. An early heater accident in a shoddy caravan lead to melted holes, weak points that no patching completely fixed. Eventually, a huge tear formed at the top, becoming so big I stopped using the zipper to access the main pouch. This was in the 8th year mind you. But the coming of the Irish rainy winter coming, and unending annoyance of passerbys letting me know my bag is open (it is perpetually open because it can’t be closed), encouraged me to move on.

The rip

To be clear, I do like reusing things as much as possible. As a point in proof, the FILBE AP isn’t even the oldest material item I still use on a weekly basis. That honor belongs to 2 shirts I got in highschool, and are probably old enough to purchase alcohol without me wearing them. Technically the FILBE AP can be patched (at significant expense), but even then, the stitching and the Velcro are unraveling, and the rain-proof zipper covers are wearing off. Patching the top would be like putting new tires on a car with a broken transmission (or battery for future generations).

Enter the Kahakka 25L

How does one go from an American military pack to a Finnish one? Well, I enjoy post-apocalyptic exclusion zones filled with mystery and mysticism. Luckily, I came across The Road to Vostok, an indie game (in the making) whose fictional Finnish setting somewhat mirrors that of the Chornobyl and Pripyat Exclusion zones in Ukraine (and similarly is taken advantage of by the STALKER video game series). Recently, Road to Vostok gained its first commercial collaboration, Savotta, where I learned of the company and its offerings at just the right time.

Savotta is a well-known Finnish supplier of outdoor gear, for both military, police, and recreational use in “extreme-environments.”

Just check out their video from a recent Road to Vostok Post:
“We are Savotta and we make military gear”

If that doesn’t convince you to buy one of their products (or want to be Finnish), well then, you’re clearly not me.

To end this introduction I’ll make a few things clear. First, I’ve never been nor am in the military. I like military packs because for equivalent rugged designs, recreational packs are much more expensive. Specifically, military packs which are GI issued. Recreational packs are also slim lined and generally don’t have PALS webbing. So, when I discuss military applications and utility, I do so out of with qualified experience. Well…Sort of. My PhD (and previous DIY hobbies) have majorly focused on physical product design and development (including apparel and hardware), so I’m keen to noticing things most people don’t. And as ridiculous as it is to say (according to critics), I often built things for the thousands of hours I used to play MilSim games (paintball, airsoft). So, I am familiar with the carrying needs for equipment and the easy access to materials while under stress.

My usage is everyday, and I mean, everything that could possibly happen in my daily life which is for better or worse, a lot. I need something that “can do it all.” Something that can be loaded up for an overnight hiking trip, or a Joe Six-pack weekend away, something to carry my groceries, something with a hip belt (but no padding), and something that can also be brought to the office, into a museum, and onto a plane (without issue).

It is a tall ask, and I am hyper critical

First Impression – and Numbers

Front View

Right Side View – Hole on top of the FILBE is partly visible

Top-Front View – The hole in the top of the FILBE is partly visible

Back View – Age related fraying on the FILBE is visible

The first time I saw the Kahakka, side by side with the FILBE, I thought, “…and this is the difference between America and Europe.”

When I go from Europe to America, or vice versa, I get “aspect ratio shock”. It’s like going from one aspect ratio on your TV, like 16:10 to 4:3 in an instant. Just it’s with real life. I haven’t heard anyone else get this, but if you do, it’d be nice to know I’m not alone.

When you go to the USA for the first time in a while, it suddenly feels like everything has gotten flattened, smashed down and really wide. The roads are so wide, that a single lane in American suburbia feels equivalent to a rural double lane in Europe. Even the landscape just seems to stretch out further. Meanwhile, go back to Europe and everything has gotten tall and skinny. Go into an older continental European home and you ain’t touchin’ that ceiling, even if you jump. In Europe, everything does seem skinnier, from the fencing to the sign posts – because it is. You just have to look at American and European printing paper if you aren’t yet convinced. Americans love their 8.5″x10″ sheets, and Europeans their 8.3″x11.7″.

If you consider most American products, they are heavier, bulkier, and luxurious (in the sense of comfort). European products are lighter, and maintain economy of material. Cars are a perfect example, even from the same manufacturer. American cars are bigger on average, and when comparing like for like between the same models, just between continents, American suspensions are far softer. While European products are trimmed, this also means they’re fitted. You can observe this in how the average person dresses in Europe versus America. Europeans are better dressed. They wear tight, hemmed clothes, pants that aren’t jeans, and aren’t necessarily blue (or black or khaki), sweaters over their button up long-sleeve shirts, and nice shoes. Oh, and each pair of socks they own are are unique. Not dozens of pairs of the same exact sock. And well….Americans, they wear that one-size-fits-all from Costco, baggy jeans, and if they’re a Dad, those classic 608 V5s (because hell, they are more comfortable).

And that is the difference between the FILBE vs the Kahakka. The FILBE is bigger, heavier, and more comfortable. By appearances, it is baggier. The Kahakka is thinner, smaller, and lighter. It is trim.

Specifications Comparison

Below is a detailed specifications comparison of the FILBE vs Kahakka. Color coded pieces depict my opinion based on experience. It does not highlight where one pack is better or worse than the other, though this is usually the case, but it highlights implementations better or worse than standard.

Guide:
Green: Very Good
Black: Standard, Acceptable
Yellow: Questionable or Uncertain
Red: Bad

However, it is estimated at 35-37L by this review which matches the review by The Outdoor Gear Review
*This is probable because I can find updated webbing for the FILBE which is marketed as being NIR compliant. However, NIR compliance wasn’t as important a decade ago

Overview

I will refer to the specifications table above, but write this review in the fashion I examined both packs side-by-side for the first time so it is more story like.

Single Handed Usage (SHU) and Fine Motor Control (FMC) are important concepts in military applications (to me) because they determine how readily a product can be used when injured (single handed usage case) and/or when under extreme stress and fine motor control becomes reduced.

Main Compartment

The Main Compartment is the heart of every pack as it will store the most material. Access to the main compartment on the Kahakka is through a Fold Top Lid secured by 2 Quick Release (SR) buckles. The female ends of these buckles are note worthy because they have flared entrances, similar to a flared magwell. This is the first time I’ve seen this on a SR buckle and I can’t even get Google Images to show me other like models (I’m sure they exist). This is a fantastic design choice, it really makes buckling easier and in a stressful situation where Fine Motor Control (FMC) goes out this window, this can make a difference.

Front of pack with 2 QR buckles and their flared inserts.

Plastic Insert on bottom lip keeps opening squared. Seam on bottom is “rough” where there is a 45 degree in the material.

“Hello darkness my old friend…” – Dark inside the main compartment, and elastic water bladder holder

Unbuckling these and the lid flips open as is common in many recreational hiking packs. Fold Top Lids are great for large recreational hiking packs. They eliminate the weaknesses of zippers while effectively using the pack’s shell to keep out the elements. But for an Assault Pack, I’m not convinced they are the right choice. They don’t provide easy enough access to materials in the main compartment.

With the Fold Top Lid fully opened, the pack becomes a long tube, too long to effectively reach the bottom. My arm length is equivalent to that of a 6′ or 183 cm man’s, and putting the Kahakka on cashier’s counter and trying to put groceries in is just not easy. For similar reasoning, larger hiking packs with Fold Top Lids now come with zippered “sleeping bag section” at the bottom. When everything must be packed from bottom-to-top, things will inevitably get pulled out of the pack to get those bottom items. In comparison, the FILBE uses a J-zip, so named because the zipper is stretches longer down one side than the other.

One great design implementation in the Kahakka is a plastic insert in lower fold top lip. This little flexible piece does a great job of keeping the mouth of the lid open and squared (I know it’s a rectangle, but rectangled doesn’t read as smoothly as a verb). There is however a seam on this lower lip (2nd photo above) which is sharp and seems to catch a lot. It is where the corner fabric I’m very concerned how this seam will hold up in time.

Inside the Main Compartment, the Kahakka has one single pouch for a water bladder. The top of the water bladder pouched is kept under tension by some kind of elastic band. There are 3 togs for which to anchor the water bladder to, although only the center one is visible in my photo. I am not a fan of elastic tensioning because these materials eventually “dry out,” lose their elasticity, and become useless. In comparison, the FILBE uses a buckle strap which will last as long as the buckle does. The FILBE does not have the locking togs the Kahakka does, but this is forgivable because this pouch is intended to hold a military radio and such togs would get in the way. Importantly, after using the FILBE with a water bladder, the lack of togs made little difference in my experience.

Both the Kahakka and FILBE have exit slots for water bladder tubes (or radio antennae). I heavily prefer the flap coverings that Savotta has used. They are located on each side of the flip top lid, just above the hemming in my photos, towards the rear of the packs. The exit slots on the FILBE are covered by Velcro and part of the top carrying handle. Despite rarely using these, they show great wear at this stage. Their top placement makes them less than ideal for inclement weather, but this may be a necessity for the intended radios antennas.

The Kahakka has no other organization in its main compartment. The FILBE has 2 “canteen” pouches. The long one is visible in my photo, beneath the short side of the J zipper. It was the perfect baguette holder. There is another “canteen” pouch on the opposite side but it is so small, it is only good for a bundle of socks. I’m not sure what the intended usage was. It seems the perfect holder for a grenade, but also where I wouldn’t want to keep one. The FILBE also has a zippered mesh pocket at the top, which I loved. Easy to access, and easy to see what was inside and where it was.

There is one thing which annoyed me greatly about the Kahakka. There is a PU coating on the inside to increase the weather resistance, a great idea, but this PU coating is a hunter’s green (i.e. a very dark green). I don’t know if this was intentional, so as to reduce any offending light signature that might be produced while looking for or at something in the main compartment at night. But it makes trying to find something in the recess of the compartment, even on a sunny day, a challenge. My constructive advice would have be to use a lighter material to reflect light further down the cavity, and if needed, use a darker coating only at the very top.

One further grievance against the Kahakka is the lack of drainage grommets. These allow water to escape the pack if it manage to get inside. The Fins and the Marines have rather different geographic sectors they are focused on. The lack of grommets may be due to the Finnish Defense Forces pack requirements, which I am wholly ignorant of, and they may have requested no external openings for drainage. With the USMC being focused on maritime operations, it is no surprise there are 5 drainage grommets in the FILBE. Even their hot weather boot has drainage (although obviously this helps with other issues).

Bottom of the FILBE - The FILBE has 5 drainage grommets, 3 in the main compartment (1 visible here, 2 outlines of the others can be seen under the PALS webbing) and 2 in the front pouch.

Bottom of the Kahakka (no grommets)

Other Notes: The FILBE has an additional “compartment” which is the zippered access above the radio/water bladder pouch. This is used for access the rigid plastic back plate of the pack, allowing one to remove it. In the past I’ve used this pouch to store documents and hide back-up cash while traveling as the zipper goes unnoticed. It is strange that a zipper was incorporated here instead of a flap as it would presumably lower production cost and weight.

Summary Trade-off (Main Compartment):

Opening the Kahakka can be done single-handedly with the QR buckles and lid, but accessing materials is restricted and difficult. Opening the FILBE can be done single-handedly, but with significantly more effort. Once opened, materials are very accessible and better organized. The organization on the FILBE is simple, but effective, while the Kahakka has no organization. The Kahakka’s internal PU coating may be good for weather-proofing but obscures items in the recess of the bag.

Pouches

The Kahakka has 4 additional pouches and pockets. The first is a patch pocket (has its own volume) which is part of the Fold Top Lid, and is accessible from the rear of the pack. This pouch is tiny. Every time I stick my hand inside it is scrapping against the zippers (which are weather proofed by a fabric over hang). It makes me wonder how it’s expected for someone wearing gloves in the Finnish winter to readily access anything besides an energy bar from it. Savotta claims, “The one on top of the lid has a capacity of ca. 3 litres, suitable for NVDs, water bottles etc.” and their Kahakka 25L video also shows them pulling out a pair of binoculars. The shape and accessibility of the pouch is certainly what makes it feel like it isn’t 3L large (and I have my doubt about fitting a 2.5L coke bottle in there). And the Savotta video shows you how someone in the Finnish winter will be accessing the compartment: by using one hand to pull the top zipper up.

I’m nervous about putting anything small and important one would normally place here, like keys because the zipper is on the lowest part of the pouch when the flip top lid is closed. Frankly, I’ve just stopped using it of instead of trying to make it work, but I’ve no doubt when I get back to hiking and camping something will get stuff inside. The Medium sized Savotta Rain Cover fits inside but I wouldn’t be putting anything else in there with it.

The next to cover is the flat pocket on the front. A flat pocket is so named because it doesn’t maintain volume of its own, but takes away volume from other places, here, the main compartment. The access is by zipper, again covered by fabric to proof it of the elements, and again it is difficult to access. There is a D-ring inside to attaching items (like keys) with a carabiner or other attachment which is nice. The pocket can just fit a Kindle Scribe (1st generation) which is 19.6 cm wide, and 22.9 cm tall (7.72″x9.06″).

Finally there are the Kahakka famous side pouches. I say this because they are always a surprising treat to every reviewer for the Kahakka as far as I can tell. And yes, they are huge pockets. These are properly 3L!
